name: q14_8
probTex:
Let $G$ be a simply connected region which is not the entire plane. Suppose that $z\in G\iff\overline z\in G$. Let $a\in G\cap\mathbb{R}$ and suppose
\[f:G\to D\]
is an biholomorphism to the unit disc with $f(a)=0, f'(a)>0$. Let $G_+=\{z\in G|Im(z)>0\}$. Prove that $f(G_+)$ lies either entirely above or entirely below the real axis.
solnTex:
We will be hopelessly lost without knowing that $f(z):G\to\mathbb{C}$ is holomorphic if and only if $g(z)=\overline{f(\overline{z})}:\overline{G}\to\overline{\mathbb{C}}$ is holomorphic (all bars mean conjugate, no topological closures in this solution). Given this lemma, the assumption that $G=\overline{G}$, and the fact that $D=\overline{D}$, we get that both $f$ and $g$ are biholomorphisms from $G$ to $D$. Moreover, $g(a)=\overline{f(\overline{a})}=\overline{f(a)}=\overline{0}=0$ and we can show (my favorite is to use Jacobians but we will skip it for now) that $g'(a)=f'(a)>0$. The Riemann mapping theorem says there is only one biolomorphism from $G$ to $D$ with this behavior at $a$, so $f=g$.
Sweet, now let's show what we want. Our required result will hold if we can show that $z\in G\cap\mathbb{R}\iff f(z)\in D\cap\mathbb{R}$. That is, $z=\overline z\iff f(z)=\overline{f(z)}$.
\[\implies\]
Suppose $z=\overline z$. Then $f(z)=g(z)=\overline{f(\overline z)}=\overline{f(z)}$.
\[\impliedby\]
Suppose $f(z)=\overline{f(z)}$. Then $\overline{f(z)}=f(z)=g(z)=\overline{f(\overline z)}$. That is, $f(z)=f(\overline z)$. Recall $f$ is, in particular, injective, so $z=\overline z$.
